descriptions.content:
The verb དགོས་ “to need” or “to have to” is used either as the main verb of a sentence or as the modal verb. It is also used as an auxiliary in the allocentric future constructions (xxlink 23.3.2 allocentric future).

Like many other languages, Tibetan has certain defective modal verbs. This is the case with verb དགོས་, insofar as there are certain restrictions about how it can be combined with auxiliaries. As a main verb it means “to need” or “to want.” དགོས་ occurs only with the following auxiliaries, and its various tenses (future, present, past) have to be deduced from the context.

Egophoric

དགོས་ཡོད་ “I need”

Negative: དགོས་མེད་

 

དགོས་ “I want”

Negative:

མི་དགོས་

Testimonial

དགོས་འདུག་ “you, he need(s)”

Negative: དགོས་མི་འདུག་

Assertive

དགོས་རེད་ “you, he need(s)”

Negative: དགོས་མ་རེད་

The suffix ཀྱི་ may be inserted between the modal and the auxiliary: དགོས་(ཀྱི་)ཡོད་, དགོས་(ཀྱི་)འདུག་, དགོས་(ཀྱི་)རེད་, but it is usually dropped in conversation. As shown above, the verb may occur alone without auxiliary དགོས་ or མི་དགོས་ and may then be best translated as “I (do not) want,” while with the auxiliary it may be translated as “need.” This negation is not pronounced mi as expected but rather is mu.

The subject of མི་དགོས་ used as a main verb must be in the dative and the object in the absolutive. In constructing a sentence, the beneficiary comes first and the patient second.

  • ངར་ཁ་བཏགས་དགོས་ཡོད། “I need offering-scarves.”
  • ངར་ཇ་མི་དགོས། “I don’t want any tea.”
  • ཁོང་ལ་ཆབ་དགོས་གནང་གི་འདུག “He needs/wants water (H).”

As a modal verb དགོས་ means “to have to,” “to need,” or even “must.” In Tibetan, unlike European languages, modal verbs such དགོས་, ཆོག་, and ཐུབ་ do not have an epistemic function and may not indicate probability or certainty (as in “he may be there, he must be there, etc.”). For the auxiliaries devoted to this function, see the discussion of epistemic mood here in the Reference Grammar (xxlink 11.3.1 epistemic); see also the discussions of the modal epistemic verb སྲིད་ (xxlink 11.3.6 modal verbs).

The modal verb དགོས་ goes with the following auxiliaries:

Future:

Assertive

དགོས་ཀྱི་རེད་

Present:

Egophoric

དགོས་(ཀྱི་)ཡོད་

 

Testimonial

དགོས་(ཀྱི་)འདུག་

 

Assertive

དགོས་(ཀྱི་)རེད་

Past (perfective):

Egophoric

དགོས་བྱུང་

 

Testimonial

དགོས་བྱུང་སོང་

 

Assertive

དགོས་བྱུང་པ་རེད་

Conjugations of དགོས་ are formed in the same way as predicative adjectives such as དགའ་པོ་ “like/be fond of.” The forms *དགོས་སོང་, *དགོས་བཞག and *དགོས་པ་རེད་ are usually not acceptable.

The case of the subject depends on the main verb.

  • རྒྱང་ཤེལ་བསྣམས་དགོས་རེད། “(We) have to take binoculars.”
  • ང་ཁ་བཏགས་ཉོ་དགོས་ཡོད། “I have to buy offering-scarves.”
  • ངས་དངུལ་སྤྲད་དགོས་བྱུང་། “I had to pay (for it).”
  • ཁོང་རི་ལིའི་ནང་ལ་ཕེབས་དགོས་བྱུང་སོང་། “He had to take the train.”
